In many other countries it is also used as a saver of lives. The Japanese use it whenever typhoons demolish their rice crops. In Uganda when a virus devastated the manioc crops, the farmers planted sweetpotato to avoid starvation. More recently, after the tsunami that ravaged southeast Asia in December 2004, the sweetpotato  demonstrated its versatility by growing in fields flooded by seawater. In Peru it is eaten as an accompaniment to some dishes, but its principal use is as forage and animal feed.

CIP, an international organization of world scope, is investigating the industrial use of the sweetpotato as fresh product. The studies that it is conducting range from the vulnerability of the plant to pests and diseases, developing efficient technologies for  post-harvest processing, increasing yield in field and the strengthening of the plant against natural threats.
item.spa_title: El camote s es una alternativa contra el hambre
item.spa_description: Exitoso empresario chino desarroll innovador mtodo para elaborar productos con camote
item.spa_content:
“El camote es un alimento crucial para resolver el problema del hambre en el mundo”, seal el empresario chino Zou Guangyou, durante su visita al Centro Internacional de la Papa (CIP) el martes 23 de agosto. El es uno de los principales productores mundiales de productos orgnicos elaborados con camote y propietario de la ms grande empresa de fabricacin de almidn y alimentos instantneos de camote en China. Se encuentra de visita en el Per por invitacin de autoridades del Ministerio de la Produccin y empresarios privados.

Durante su estada en el pas viene celebrando reuniones con diversos sectores vinculados a la produccin de camote y agroindustria del pas. Sin embargo, mostr un inters especial en visitar el CIP “donde todo empez”, segn sus palabras. En efecto, segn relat durante la conferencia que dict a empresarios, investigadores y autoridades en el CIP, en 1990, Zhou era un funcionario estatal de Shantai, una provincia pobre de China donde la transformacin de camote en fideos de fcula era una de las pocas fuentes de ingresos de los campesinos locales.

Pero la visita de varios cientficos del CIP, que tena por objeto estudiar las prcticas poscosecha de camote, le cambi la vida; se inscribi en el curso de procesamiento de camote que dictaron y se dio cuenta de la demanda potencial para fideos instantneos de harina de camote en vez de los de harina de trigo que dominaban el mercado.

Sus clculos eran clarsimos: del camote a la fcula, el valor aumentaba en 100 por ciento: de la fcula a los fideos de fcula normales, en 200 por ciento. Si la fcula se transformaba en fideos instantneos, el valor poda incrementarse en 2000 por ciento. Un mes despus del curso, Zhou dej su puesto estatal para establecer una pequea fbrica de fideos. Su inversin inicial fueron 60 dlares, hoy Zhou es millonario, pero los comienzos fueron difciles: “en un triciclo, muerto de fro tratando de interesar a los compradores en las bondades del nuevo producto”, record.

Cinco aos despus, en 1995, la fbrica de Zhou trabajaba febrilmente para abastecer la demanda y para satisfacerla, invent una mquina extractora de fcula: la ‘minimquina de Guang-you’, que transformaba 2 toneladas de camote fresco al da, 20 veces ms que el mtodo manual tradicional, que usa mano de obra intensiva.

La nueva tecnologa transform los fideos de camote de un bien de consumo rural de poco valor en un producto alimenticio de alta calidad que se exporta a mercados tan exigentes como Canad y Estados Unidos. La mquina de transformacin permite producir fideos todo el ao y, lo ms importante, se adeca a la elaboracin familiar en pequea escala, lo que ha concitado el inters de no pocos empresarios peruanos.

Actualmente, las ventas anuales de su empresa superan los 8 millones de dlares y produce alrededor de 30 productos diferentes elaborados a partir del camote, en su mayor parte fideos tradicionales chinos totalmente orgnicos. Da trabajo directo a ms de mil personas, pero mantiene un centro de capacitacin permanente en su empresa al que acuden a recibir entrenamiento campesinos de todo el pas.

Ese centro, segn Zhou, forma parte del primer eslabn de su “cadena de comercializacin”, que, en ltima instancia busca integrar las innovaciones producto de la investigacin con el mercado, generando ingresos a los agricultores. Por eso, los otros dos eslabones son la interaccin con los investigadores y la bsqueda de nuevos mercados.

Aunque sus productos se centran en el camote, tambin viene realizando investigaciones con la papa, producto que en la China tiene una tradicin de consumo de casi 500 aos, porque en su opinin, tanto la papa como el camote son dos alimentos de primer orden con innumerables propiedades industriales y medicinales.

Durante su visita al CIP, el empresario chino se mostr asombrado por la calidad de las investigaciones que en l se realizan. “El CIP me abri los ojos sobre las posibilidades del camote y despus de esta visita, me ha dado ms valor para seguir adelante”, seal.

Respecto a las particularidades del camote seal que en la China se le atribuyen propiedades cosmticas, “se asegura que su consumo constante vuelve la piel ms lozana”, refiri. “Adems, es un alimento ditetico, muy sano, contiene micronutrientes y su almidn posee muy bajas caloras”, afirm.

Investigaciones realizadas por el CIP han comprobado que cien gramos de camote de pulpa anaranjada proporciona ms del cien por ciento del betacaroteno requerido diariamente por el organismo humano, es decir ms vitamina A de la que proporcionan 100 g. de zanahoria. Precisamente por esta cualidad, est siendo usado en el Africa para prevenir la ceguera infantil causada por insuficiencia de vitamina A.

En muchos otros pases tambin es usado como salvador de vidas: los japoneses lo usan cada vez que los tifones arrasan sus cultivos de arroz, en Uganda cuando un virus devast los cultivos de yuca, se us camote para evitar que los pobladores murieran de hambre y, ms recientemente, con el tsunami que asol el sudeste de Asia en diciembre, el camote ha demostrado su versatilidad para crecer en campos inundados por la salinidad de las aguas de mar. En el Per se consume como acompaamiento de algunos platos, pero su uso principal es como forraje y alimento de animales.

En el CIP, un organismo internacional de alcance mundial, se investiga el uso del camote como producto fresco y para potenciar su uso industrial. Los estudios que realiza van desde la vulnerabilidad de la planta frente a plagas y enfermedades, hasta tecnologas eficientes de procesamiento poscosecha, incluyendo el incremento del rendimiento en campo y el fortalecimiento de la planta contra fenmenos naturales.

item.title: Canada and CIP sign Project that will benefit the Altiplano of Peru and Bolivia
item.description: Thousands of families that live in the altiplano of Peru and Bolivia will see their living conditions improved in the coming years, through an important project that was signed on 3 August by the Ambassador of Canada, Genevive de Rivires, and the Director General of the International Potato Center (CIP), Dr. Pamela K. Anderson.
item.eng_content:
The 5-year project will be financed by the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) of the government of Canada at a cost of 10 million Canadian dollars. Its beneficiaries will be 42,000 families that live in 700 native rural communities and depend on agriculture for their livelihoods.

The project is called "Andean Agriculture in the Altiplano: Achieving Sustainable Rural Development in the Peru-Bolivia Altiplano through the Improvement of Andean Agriculture." The agreement was signed at noon in the headquarters of CIP in the district of La Molina in Lima.

"This work will help to reach the Millennium Development Goals of the United Nations, and - among other things - it will improve human health through food security and better nutrition," commented Dr. Anderson.

“The Peru-Bolivia Altiplano is home to 6 million people, three quarters of whom live in poverty. Around 55 % live in extreme poverty, facing problems like low agricultural productivity, natural resource degradation and marginalization. These conditions are forcing the people to migrate to cities and the Amazon area, causing severe environmental and social disruption,” she added.

In turn, the ambassador of Canada pointed out that this project will help to reduce poverty in isolated regions in the altiplano and to improve governance and the self-sufficiency at local level. Similarly, it will make it possible to develop the private sector, it will contribute to environmental protection and to the empowerment of women.

The ambassador added that the Canadian funds would be used to promote the investment and development of microcompanies devoted to marketing the crops. It will also promote technologies of conservation of water and biodiversity.

Dr. Hugo Li Pun, in charge of the project, said that the objective "is to improve the living conditions of the rural communities in the altiplano of Peru and Bolivia."

”Our objective is to improve the livelihood of rural communities in the Peru-Bolivia Altiplano, said CIP’s Dr. Hugo Li Pun, who is in charge of the Altiplano project. “CIP and our partners have worked successfully in that area for the past two decades and obtained impressive results among the native communities. We have increased our understanding of their livelihood strategies and complex agricultural systems. Through that understanding we have been able to improve agricultural technologies, community organization, credit schemes and the processing of agricultural products like potatoes, quinoa, oca, milk, meat, alpaca and fiber. The net impact has been to raise the standard of living of the local people.”

CIP’s partner in the project will include national organizations, universities, nongovernmental and farmer organizations, among others.

Day: 3 August      
Hour: 10.30 a.m..
Place: Av. The University 1895, La Molina (facing the Agrarian University)

For more information, contact:
International Potato Center
Zoraida Portillo, Press Coordinator
Tel. 3496017. ext. 3105-/z.portillo@cgiar.org

Embassy of Canada
Luz Mara Correa, Public Relations and Press
Tel: 444-4015, ext. 3324  - LuzMaria.Correa@international.gc.ca
item.spa_title: Canad y CIP suscriben proyecto que beneficiar al Altiplano de Per y Bolivia
item.spa_description: Miles de familias que habitan en el altiplano de Per y Bolivia vern mejoradas sus condiciones de vida en los prximos aos, en virtud a un importante proyecto que suscribieron el 3 de agosto la Embajadora de Canad, Genevive des Rivires, y la Directora General del Centro Internacional de la Papa (CIP), doctora Pamela K. Anderson.
item.spa_content:
El proyecto tendr una duracin de cinco aos y ser financiado por la Agencia Canadiense para el Desarrollo Internacional (ACDI) del gobierno de Canad a un costo de 10 millones de dlares. Sus beneficiarios sern 42.000 familias que habitan en 700 comunidades campesinas nativas, cuyo principal sustento es la agricultura.

El proyecto se denomina "Agricultura Andina en el Altiplano: Alcanzando el Desarrollo Rural Sostenible en el Altiplano Peruano-Boliviano mediante el Mejoramiento de la Agricultura Andina". El convenio respectivo ser suscrito al medioda en la sede central del CIP en el distrito de La Molina.

"Este trabajo contribuir a alcanzar los Objetivos de Desarrollo del Milenio de las Naciones Unidas, pues -entre otras cosas- mejorar la salud humana mediante la seguridad alimentaria y una mejor nutricin," coment la doctora Anderson.

"El altiplano peruano-boliviano alberga a 6 millones de personas, de las cuales tres cuartas partes viven en pobreza. Alrededor de 55% viven en situacin de pobreza extrema, afrontando problemas como baja productividad agrcola y marginacin. Estas condiciones obligan a las personas a migrar a las ciudades y a las reas amaznicas, causando graves problemas ambientales y sociales", subray.

Por su parte, la embajadora de Canad destac que este proyecto contribuir a reducir la pobreza en regiones aisladas del altiplano y a mejorar la gobernabilidad y la autosuficiencia a nivel local; de igual manera, permitir desarrollar del sector privado, contribuir a la proteccin del medio ambiente y al empoderamiento de la mujer.

La embajadora agreg que la contribucin canadiense servira para promover la inversin y el desarrollo de micro empresas dedicadas a comercializar los productos agrcolas. Tambin promover tecnologas de conservacin del agua y de la biodiversidad.

El Dr. Hugo Li Pun, encargado del proyecto, declar que el objetivo "es mejorar las condiciones de vida de las comunidades rurales en el altiplano de Per y Bolivia".

"El CIP y sus socios hemos trabajado exitosamente en esa rea durante las dos ltimas dcadas, obteniendo resultados notables entre las comunidades nativas. Hemos aumentado nuestra comprensin sobre las estrategias de sobrevivencia y los complejos sistemas agrcolas. Gracias a ello, hemos podido contribuir a mejorar las tecnologas agrcolas, la organizacin comunitaria, los sistemas de crdito y el procesamiento de productos agrcolas como papa, quinua, oca, leche, carne y la fibra de alpaca. El impacto directo ha sido un incremento en el nivel de vida de los habitantes locales", seal.

Los socios del CIP en este proyecto incluirn organizaciones nacionales y locales, universidades, organizaciones no gubernamentales y de agricultores, entre otros.

item.title: Resistance to late blight still "robust" say researchers
item.description: Resistance to late blight remains strong in some of the most popular varieties of potatoes. This is the conclusion of a large international study* that tested the stability of resistance of 14 potato genotypes to the fungus Phytophthora infestans, which causes late blight.
item.eng_content:
Late blight is one of the most destructive diseases of potato, with the potential of wiping out whole crops. The most effective weapon against the disease is to breed varieties that resist the disease. However, over time, this resistance could break down, so breeders are continually trying to find or develop new and more resistant material. In fact, several recent studies found signs that the pathogen is capable of overcoming complicated resistance barriers, so adaptation is a real threat. For example, P. infestans was recently found to be attacking previously resistant potato species in the Netherlands.

The study, which was led by the International Potato Center (CIP), based in Lima, Peru, involved 10 institutions in nine countries, ranging from Argentina to the Netherlands. Researchers tested the durability of resistance by evaluating the same set of potato cultivars in various locations over a period of three years.

Overall, resistance to P. infestans was robust, said CIPs Greg Forbes, who led the study. Resistant genotypes were consistently resistant in all the locations, representing a wide range of latitudes and altitudes. Tropically adapted resistant materials resisted the pathogen  in the temperate areas of this study, and varieties from Scotland were resistant in Quito, Ecuador.

Adaptation of existing pathogen populations to resistance in the clones also did
not appear to be a problem, said William Fry of Ithaca University, who oversaw some of the trials, because the same genotypes were resistant in all locations.

The study itself is significant because papers reporting research on the subject are rare. Severe logistical problems have previously limited multilocation trials involving potato, because the tubers are perishable, expensive to multiply and ship, and difficult to maintain in a disease-free state that satisfies strict quarantine regulations. It was this lack of information on the broad geographical stability of quantitative resistance to late blight that led us to develop the project, said Forbes.

Information on the stability of potato is extremely important, for yield, disease resistance or other traits, because potato is such a cosmopolitan crop. However, not all potato genotypes have the ability to grow well in different environments. This has incited potato breeders to seek genotypes with broad adaptability. Knowledge of the environmental stability of resistance is essential to this effort, concluded Forbes.

*See: G. A. Forbes et al.  Stability of resistance to Phytophthora infestans in potato: an international evaluation. Plant Pathology (2005) 54, 364372 Doi: 10.1111/j.1365-3059.2005.01187.x

item.title: Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Leader
item.description: The International Potato Center (CIP) is pleased to announce that as of mid-October 2005 , Dr. Jan Low is joining CIP as the Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Leader, to be based at Nairobi.
item.eng_content:
Having spent nearly all of her professional career in Sub-Saharan Africa, Dr. Low has broad and extensive experience in the integration of nutritional concerns into agricultural policy and programs and the role of roots and tubers in farming systems. She has lived and worked in DR Congo, Malawi, Kenya and most recently Mozambique. She previously worked for CIP as a Rockefeller Post-Doctoral Fellow based in Nairobi so in reality we are welcoming her back.

As Regional Leader, Dr. Low will head research and outreach efforts in Sub-Saharan Africa, one of CIP’s four global regions.  As leader and manager of the CIP-SSA office and team, she will have primary responsibility for providing scientific leadership for CIP in the region. This includes developing the regional goals and strategies, leading resource mobilization, and guiding the scientific team and its partners to ensure that research outputs contribute to poverty and hunger reduction and nutrition improvement.  She will also work closely with African research networks and national agricultural research programs in planning and coordinating CIP's research.  Dr. Low is completing a research project comparing changes in vitamin A intake and levels of vitamin A deficiency between villages in Mozambique adopting and not adopting orange-fleshed sweetpotato.

item.title: CIP celebrates National Potato Day
item.description: As part of the national celebrations of Peru’s first National Potato Day, CIP held an open day on the theme of the technology and germplasm of the potato. The display was held in association with the Government’s multisectoral commission for the celebration at CIP’s headquarters in Lima, Peru on 28 May 2005.
item.eng_content:
“We meet to recognize the contribution that this crop has made to this nation, to the Americas, and to the rest of the world, where the potato is the fourth most important crop in world agriculture,” said Dr Pamela K. Anderson, the Director General of CIP.

The Vice Minister of Agriculture and president of the multisectoral commission Julio Escudero Meza inaugurated the event, and also announced the campaign to "Buy Peruvian Potatoes" that the Ministry of Production was promoting. Later, the more than 200 guests and journalists heard a series of presentations about the cultural and agronomic aspects of the biodiversity of the potato. These talks were followed by a discussion of the production process of the potato, which was backed up by a live demonstration of all aspects of the market chain, from harvesting through grading, distribution and wholesaling to the actual sales point in the supermarket.

“We believe that this is a good way to help the producers of potato and especially the poorer farmers,” said Dr Andersen. “We hope to obtain tangible results in the near future, as further contributions to the efforts of the Peruvian Government in this area.”

Before the live demonstration began, farmers from the “Potato Park” performed a traditional ceremony dedicated to the potato gods. The Potato Park was developed with CIP by the Association for Nature and Sustainable Development and six indigenous communities in Pisaq, Cusco. Local communities conserve hundreds of varieties of native Andean potatoes in a local model of the sustainable use of agrobiodiversity, and promotion and protection of the associated resources, knowledge and traditional practices.

Representatives from the industry described innovations in opening up new markets for the potato, such as potato chips made from yellow potato, which has significantly less starch and so absorbs less fat during cooking, producing a lower calories snack. Even a move from the traditional 120-kg sack to a more easily managed 50-kg bag has had a significant impact in reducing damage to the tubers being shipped. The largest supermarket chain in Peru, E. Wong, participated, with the creation of a sales point displaying the many different varieties of the potato that it sells.

“We want to renew our commitment to Peru to continue to collaborate in the improvement and conservation of this great national treasure that is the potato,” said Dr Anderson.

Operating under the slogan, “not just potatoes, more than potatoes”, the open day also featured a competition among three of the largest culinary schools in Lima. With over thirty innovative dishes to choose from, both savory and sweet, the judges awarded each school a prize, including one for a salmon-stuffed yellow potato ravioli with a sauce of rocoto, a South American capsicum that has been cultivated in Peru for thousands of years. The presentations were made by Mrs Rossy Masalas from the Crculo Gastronmico del Per.

Other activities included as series of open conferences organized between CIP and  the National Agrarian University. The Ministry of Agriculture sponsored a Potato Fair from 26 to 30 May where potato producers from all over the country will sold special potatoes, which were also available for tasting.

item.title: New Director General takes over International Potato Center
item.description: Dr. Pamela Anderson took over as the new Director-General of the International Potato Center, from 1 May, replacing Dr. Hubert Zandstra, who directed CIP from 1991.
item.eng_content:
A native of the United States, Dr. Anderson is an internationally recognized entomologist and ecologist who has worked at CIP since June 2002 as Deputy Director-General of Research.

A expert in emerging diseases of plants, Dr. Anderson has conducted research in aspects of virology, ecology, the production of food, human health and agricultural development for farmers of limited resources. She has spent more than 25 years working in various countries of Latin America, and for more than a decade has devoted herself to working in close coordination with nation al agricultural research systems.

One of her first tasks as Deputy Director of Research was to guide the development of a new vision for the Center, redefining its programs of research and development to harmonize them with the Millennium Development Goals of the United Nations.

A fruitful collaboration
The work of Dr. Zandstra as Director General for 14 tears has been highly fruitful, not only in Peru, but also in agricultural research in various areas and ecosystems of the world. One of his principal concerns was the conservation and use of genetic resources, so the construction at CIP of the Biodiversity Complex was a major accomplishment. The Complex contains buildings with the most advanced technology and biotechnology that house unique collections of potato, sweet potato and Andean roots and tubers endemic in Latin America.

Furthermore, Dr. Zandstra turned the work of CIP to include the sustainable management of natural resources, especially of the mountain areas of the world, and expand research on the environmental impact of agriculture. It was in that context that CIP created CONDESAN, a consortium of institutions that work for the development of the Andean ecoregion, and launched the Global Mountain Program initiative, to coordinate efforts for the development of the Andes, the Himalayas and mountain chains of the East Africa.

Dr. Zandstra also directed institutional efforts to the restoration of the rich biological diversity of the Andean region and, specifically, to the rescue of nine Andean roots and tubers that were found at the verge of the extinction and which were fundamental to the diet and income generation of the rural people of the Andes.

Peru has benefited from much of this work.  For example, work in conserving genetic resources has allowed 2,700 samples of virus-free native potatoes to be restored to 35 high Andean communities. Two Andean food species, yacon and maca, have been saved from extinction and are now known and valued internationally. Other research on Andean crops with a market-driven approach has brought benefit to the poor producers who have conserved them from generation to generation.

The future
"The major directions of CIP’s work will continue to deepen and widen in the future", said Dr. Anderson on receiving a traditional staff symbolizing the handing over of power from her predecessor during an internal ceremony at CIP, in presence of more that 300 workers.

CIP was funded in 1971 by Dr. Richard Sawyer, another eminent international scientist and recognized expert in the culture of potato, who was its first director. CIP is currently one of the 15 international centers of the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research (CGIAR). CIP works to reduce poverty and achieve the sustainable food security in developing countries through scientific research and other activities related to potato, sweet potato and other Andean roots and tubers, together with better management of the natural resources of the Andes and other mountain areas.

The Molina, May 2005.
item.spa_title: Renombrada cientfica internacional dirigir Centro Internacional de la Papa
item.spa_description: A partir del 1 de mayo, la Dra. Pamela Anderson es la nueva Directora General del Centro Internacional de la Papa, en reemplazo del Dr. Hubert Zandstra, quien dirigi el CIP desde 1991 y est prximo a jubilarse.
item.spa_content:
Natural de los Estados Unidos, la Dra. Anderson es una Entomloga y Ecologista muy reconocida internacionalmente. Trabaja en el CIP desde junio de 2002 como Directora General Adjunta de Investigacin.

Experta en enfermedades emergentes de plantas, la Dra. Anderson ha realizado diversas investigaciones en virologa, ecologa, produccin de alimentos, salud humana y desarrollo agrcola para agricultores de escasos recursos. Lleva ms de 25 aos trabajando en diversos pases de Amrica Latina, y ms de una dcada los ha dedicado a trabajar en estrecha coordinacin con los sistemas nacionales de investigacin agrcola.

Una de sus primeras tareas como Directora Adjunta de Investigacin, fue guiar la elaboracin de una nueva Visin del Centro, redefiniendo sus programas de investigacin y desarrollo para armonizarlos con los Objetivos de Desarrollo del Milenio de la ONU.

Una conduccin fructfera
Por su parte, la labor del Dr. Zandstra como Director del CIP durante 14 aos ha sido altamente fructfera no slo para el Per sino para la investigacin agrcola en diversas partes y ecosistemas del mundo. Una de sus principales preocupaciones fue la conservacin y uso de los recursos genticos. En esa perspectiva, se construy el Complejo de Biodiversidad, un moderno edificio con los ltimos adelantos tecnolgicos en biotecnologa, donde se albergan los bancos genticos de papa, camote y races y tubrculos andinos, que es nico en su gnero en Amrica Latina.

Asimismo, ampli el mbito de trabajo del CIP hacia el manejo sostenible de los recursos naturales, especialmente de las zonas de montaa de todo el mundo, y profundiz las investigaciones sobre el impacto ambiental de la agricultura. Fue en ese contexto que el CIP cre CONDESAN, un consorcio de instituciones que trabajan por el desarrollo de la ecorregin andina, y lanz la iniciativa del Programa Mundial de Montaas, para concertar esfuerzos para el desarrollo de los Andes, los Himalayas y las cadenas montaosas del frica oriental.

Tambin dirigi los esfuerzos institucionales a la restauracin de la rica diversidad biolgica de la regin andina y, especficamente, al rescate de nueve races y tubrculos andinos que se encontraban al borde de la extincin y que cumplen una funcin primordial en la alimentacin y generacin de ingresos de los campesinos de los Andes.

El Per se ha beneficiado en forma privilegiada de los esfuerzos conducidos por el Dr. Zandstra. Por ejemplo, los trabajos de preservacin de recursos genticos han posibilitado que hasta el momento, en 35 comunidades altoandinas se hayan restaurado 2,700 muestras de papas nativas libres de virus; que el yacn y la maca por slo citar dos cultivos se hayan salvado de la extincin y ahora sean conocidos y valorados internacionalmente y que las investigaciones sobre los cultivos andinos tengan un enfoque de mercado para beneficio de los productores pobres que los han preservado generacin tras generacin.

“Los grandes lineamientos de trabajo del CIP continuarn profundizndose y amplindose en el futuro”, declar la Dra. Anderson al recibir simblicamente el mando de parte de su predecesor durante una ceremonia interna, realizada en el CIP, en presencia de sus ms de 300 trabajadores.

El CIP fue fundado en 1971 por el Dr. Richard Sawyer, otro eminente cientfico internacional y reconocido experto en el cultivo de papa, quien adems fue su primer director. Actualmente el CIP es uno de los 15 centros internacionales del Grupo Consultivo para la Investigacin Agrcola Internacional (CGIAR). El CIP busca reducir la pobreza y alcanzar la seguridad alimentaria sobre bases sostenibles en los pases en desarrollo, mediante la investigacin cientfica y actividades relacionadas en papa, camote y otras races y tubrculos y un mejor manejo de los recursos naturales en los Andes y otras zonas de montaa.

La Molina, mayo 2005.

item.title: CIP Board honors outgoing Director General
item.description: The Board of Trustees of the International Potato Center (CIP) has dedicated the CIP Biodiversity Complex to Hubert Zandstra, the Director General, who is retiring at the end of April 2005 after 14 years of service.
item.eng_content:
Many members of Peru’s diplomatic corps, representatives of the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Agriculture and national organizations of Peru, donor representatives, Board members and staff attended the ceremony, which took place on 14 March 2005.

“Hubert has long been interested in conserving and repatriating varieties of potatoes, sweetpotatoes and other roots and tubers,” said James Godfrey, the Chair of the Board. “He was instrumental in establishing the biodiversity complex so it is a fitting tribute to him that after 14 years as Director General of CIP we dedicate the complex to him.”

Renamed the Hubert Zandstra Biodiversity Complex, the genebank was opened in 2001 and now maintains more than 28,000 accessions of 282 species of potato, sweetpotato and other Andean root and tuber crops under state-of-the-art conditions. CIP holds this important collection in trust under an agreement with the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.  “We are committed to its conservation and characterization on behalf of the international community, and to its fair and unrestricted availability,” said Zandstra.

Dr. Zandstra was the driving force in the design, development and funding of the complex, planning for which started in 1998. “This is indeed a very emotional moment for me,” said Zandstra. “The Biodiversity Complex provides a much needed home for the diversity of root and tuber crops that ensure tomorrow’s food security and the livelihood and quality of life for several billion people around the world.”

Dr. Zandstra recalled the special effort it took to complete the facility; the financial risk CIP took, the strong support from its core donors and in particular the special support from Japan, which made the construction possible, and the World Bank for helping to equip the facility. “Peru and the region now have a first class international quality facility that will safeguard the biodiversity heritage of this region,” he said.
 
The CIP facility, along with many others in developing and developed countries, form an international network of genebanks holding plant genetic resources as global public goods.  Use of these collections is guided by principles of access and benefit sharing of the Convention of Biological Diversity. The International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture recently enacted this convention as international law.  Peru has formally adopted this Treaty and thus became the first country to do so in the Andean region.

Dr. Zandstra retires on 30 April, to be succeeded by Dr. Pamela Anderson, CIP’s present Deputy Director General of Research. Commenting on Dr. Zandstra’s tremendous contributions to CIP, James Godfrey said, “In Hubert's vision he realized CIP could not stay just as a commodity center. He established CIP as a center for natural resource management incorporating successfully social science with biological and natural science to develop research priorities and sustainable systems to help communities in vulnerable areas.”

Dr. Orlando Olcese, Peruvian Board member, cofounder of CIP and representative of the Agrarian University of La Molina, Peru, spoke lengthily and entertainingly on the origins of CIP and Dr. Zandstra’s contributions. He stressed the importance of the collection, the Andean region’s and especially Peru’s important contribution to the collection. “The original objective of the center was to keep the enormous biodiversity of the potato in Peru for the benefit of humanity,” he said. “Hubert Zandstra has clearly understood the importance of this task and the building you are looking at today is a testimony to his efforts to conserve potato germplasm.” The renaming of the complex will also serve as a fitting tribute and reminder of the tremendous contribution that Hubert Zandstra made to the development of CIP during his long and fruitful tenure.

item.title: CIP signs innovative agreement with local farmers to conserve native potatoes
item.description: Under the scheme, CIP scientists and local farmers are working together to establish domesticated varieties and wild potato relatives from CIP's germplasm collection in a 'potato park'.
item.eng_content:
The park is located in Pisac in the Sacred Valley of the Incas, in the department of Cusco. Six rural communities live in the park, which spreads over 12 thousand hectares between 3400 and 4500 meters above sea level. Administered by the local people themselves, this initiative is an example of local conservation and sustainable use of the agrobiodiversity, because the park also provides food for the communities.

Local farmers in Peru cultivate more than 2000 varieties of native potatoes, most of which are not sold commercially. They are the result of a process of natural selection and of arduous domestication with ancestral technologies that date back to pre-Inca times. That local knowledge is precisely what the framework of the agreement is intended to protect, by keeping the control of genetic resources with the local people.

The document is the first of its kind to be signed in Peru and in the CGIAR. It is a prime example of the practical application of international treaties on the access to the genetic resources, such as the Convention on Biodiversity and the International Treaty on Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture of FAO.

Alejandro Argumedo, associate director of the Association for Nature and Sustainable Development, the group that has assumed the representation of the six rural communities that form the Potato Park, believes that it could serve as a model for other indigenous communities. "Biological diversity is best rooted in its natural environment and managed by indigenous peoples who know it best," says Argumedo.

In a commentary, the international science weekly New Scientist wrote, "Deals like this one prevent multinational seed companies patenting traditional varieties of crops to exploit their native genes. This practice has sometimes forced communities to pay fees for growing seeds they originally bred."

The Inter Press Service News Agency noted that several policy analysts and civil society campaigners are preparing to push for similar initiatives at a meeting of the Convention on Biological Diversity to be held in Bangkok in February, and at a World Intellectual Property Organisation meeting to be held in Geneva in June.
